div.p: Document image analysis i s the subfield of digital image prnccssiiig that aims at converting document images to symbolic form for modification, storage, rctrieval, reuse, arid transmission. On tlie o h c r hand, push1 addrvsscs, printed arliclcs, burcaucratir forms, sheet miisic, engineering drawings, and topographic maps represent symbolic objects. We t1icrcfrn.c propose the following working dcfinitiun:
Dwunimt image analysis (UIA) is the theory and practice of recovering the symbol strocture of digital images scanned from p a p or produced by computer.

For ease of reading, pictures of symbols tend to bc produced with high contriist: most text and line art is essciitially black-on-whitc. Color is applicd wherc IICCESsilry, without fine tonal gradations (though trendy inagazincs often splash color without regard for lcgibility). l'hokngraphs arc rcproduccd as halftones. Accordingly, linear signal-anal ysi s tcchni ques bawd on freqiiency lrnnsforms are less prevalent iii 13IA than in computer visjon and in natural picture prticcssing.

There is considerable current interest in recognizing incidental text (license plates, billboards, and subtitles) in photographs aiid video. Once a document is segmentcd into its constituent components, more specific tcclmiques are nuedcd. Traditionally the field has differentiated between .msIIy text and ir~osHy graphics documents. Mostly-tcxt pages are separated into columns, paragraph-blocks, text-lines, words, and characters. OCR converts the individual word or character images into B character code like ASCI[ nr Unicodc. Specialized techniqucs arc! appropriate and affordable for high-volume text applicaiions likc ciivelopes, business letters, bank-checks, and invoices.

Engineering drawings, maps, music SCCII'CS, schematic diagrams, and organization charts are examples of mostlygraphics documents. Iine drawings are deconiposed into straight-linc and curve segments, junctions and crossings before higher-level components, such as dimcnsions, center-lines, and cross-hatching can be interpreted. At every stage of research, it is essential t o bc able to display the results of processing in a form suitable for human judgment. Accurate rendering of digitizcd pictures at various scales requircs some care.

Here we have opted to group dcicunients into only two types. The major decision Is top-down vs. bottom-up analysis. div.head: Linguistic Context
div.p: Character N-grams have been used for contextual OCR error crmcction since the mid-sixties, when large lexicons could not yet be stored, but tlic first large-scale computational shidy of their relevant characteristics was Suw's [79]. Suen tabulabed word-lengths, the growth in the number of distinct n-grams as a function of vocabulary sizc, their word-positional dependence, and the influence of the selected corpus on n-grain statistics. He advocated taking into consideration the "context" of the text, such as "novel, proper names, news items, coinputer programs, etc." The ciitropy of N-grams (N 5 5) of English dictionary words (without rcgard to word frequency) was later studied from an information-theoretic point of view [9h].

Shinghal and Toussaint [72], [73] conductcd extensive studies on tlic application of Markovian assumpticiixi to Bayesian classification. Thcy popularized the Viterbi algorithm for finding the highest-probability path thrtiugh the word-trellis of recognition candidates and intrtiduccd modifications to acccleratc the computation, They also investigated the sensitivity of the rcsiilts to the source skatistics, and the appropriate application of thc confusion probabilities of a given classifier. Hull and Srihari [31] bridge lexical and morphological (N-gram) error correction by quantizing N-gram frequencies to 1 or 0 depending on whcthcr the N-gram occurs in a lexicon of valid words. hltcrnatives for combining the two approachcs wcre compared in [32]. Hcrc the Viterbi algorithm was used to produce the most likely outcome, constrained by the presence of the output word in a lcxicon. Srihari's 1985 Cnmpritcr Society tutorial, Computer Text .Rccqnitiorr arid Error Currcction, remains a valuable reference on this topic.

A serious effort to extend hybrid cmtcxtual correction to real-life wide-vocabulary documents that may contain abbreviations and proper nouns that do not appcar in the lexicon, and to misscgmciitcd classifier output, was presented in [75]. The most. likely M-gram based word is augmented by candidates (word-hypotlrescs) within a small string-edit distance, thus providing additional lexical candidates and allowing for the possibility of missegmentation. Spccial handlers are developed for numerals, punctuation, all-cap words, ctc. Thc final hypothesis selection is based on a cost model that takes into account the confusion matrix, the lexicon, trigram frequencies, as well as transient information crdlcctud fi.om words reliably recognized elsewhere in the same document.

A word-recognition method based on Left-Right-Toph t h m (almost 2D) Hidden Markov Model (HMM) was prnposcd for spotting keywords on poorly scanned pagcs [4&]. On a test of 26,000 words, 99 pcrccnt accuracy was achieved 011 the same font sizc, but the recognition deteriorated on variable-sized fonts.

Striving to eliminate completcly character-level segmentation errors, Hi111 [33] recognixed entire sentei~ces using a probabilistic parts-of-speech grammar. ' Thc rccognition primitives here are clustwed word shapes (a group of 10 visually similar words is called a ncigiibouhood.) The procedure is similar to that of a I-IMM that links word candidates with t hhc pnrt-of-speech transition probabilities. The experimental results on simulated data generated from R coded corpus of text support the inclusion of probabilistic grammars in the contcxtunl OCR rcpertory. Such grammars can be generated for any language and splwrc of discourse with rl computer-readable corpus of: text.

In a refreshing departure from natural language context, I3aird and Thompson [SI, taking advantage of the tight constraitits nn chess text, built a system that transcribed 142 complete games from the poorly-printed Chess Infonlmnt. They interpreted all but three of the games correctly, corresponding to 99.99 percent accuracy on moves and to 99.995 percent on characters. l'he base shapc analysis was onhp 94.5 percent correct. 'The context here includes the pcrmissiblu combinations of symbols (syntnx) and the permissible sequences of mtives (scnrantius). By luck, the semantic analyzer was already availablc frrtiin Bcllc, tlw computer cliess champion. This paper reprcscnts a wondcr-hi1 example of the power of context in the right crmtext.

The recognition methods described so far are all bawd on some preconception of the character shapcs. It is, however, possible to cluster well-fnrmcd charactcr bihnaps without any such precnnception or trainhig. The rcsulting 26 cluster Idwls can then be replaced with the corresponding alphabetic labels by solving thc substitution cipher generated by thc rcading ordcr of the cluster labels [59J. 'l'lie Achilles' heel of this scheme is "imperfect" clustering, which inay separate equivalent forms of thc same class (E & e), merge different cfasses {c & c ) , and crcatc nonconforming clusters iiconoclosts) of touching and brnkcn characters, digits, and punctuation.

Recently, BBN researchers drew on thcir HMM tools for speech and handwrittcn-characlor recognition to develop a m LL I ti font read er wit t i lar~g uage-indcpcndcnt algorithms and shapu fcahms, and langunge-dependent orthographic rulcs, charactcr mnduls, lexicons, and grammars 161. The o r h g r a p h i c rules specify thc orionto tion and reading order o f tlic script. 'I'hc charactcr models arc 14-state transition graphs oE feature vectors extracted from nai'row overlapping bars Ifi.nn/es) orthogonal to a text linc. Thc word models are concatenated ctiarackr models. Tlw language model ( p i i i i i i z n ~) coiisists of cvord-bigram frequencies derived independently from the scanned training set.

Recognition is based on multimodal Gaussian distributions for the feature vectoi:s. It is assitined that different modes correspond to different styles of print. However, the formulation appears to estimate the style of each frame separately instead of conditioning the eiitirc character 011 the style. This results in an unexpected exponential in the estimated style probabilities, which surfaces in cxpcriments on italic and plain fonts. It is compensated by Bazzi et al. [6] by manipulating the proportions of differcnt styles in the training data.

The system was tested on larg-c tost sets from the University of Washington, English Documcnt Iiiiagc Dntiibase and from the DARPA Arabic OCR Corps. Thc rcstilts indicated that using a 30,000-word English Icxicon iInd word-bigram frequencies reduces the erroi, rate by about a factor of three over use of character bigrams and trigrams alone (called open vocobular!j recopition). Coinbining them gives almost another factor of two. The error rate on Hnglish was about three times lower than on Arabic. The authors speculate that this was caused by the intrinsic similarity of some Arabic characters, their connectedness and ligatures, wider font diversity, and lnwcr print quality.

Now, we incntion thrcc papcrs that dcvclopcd tcchniques for otlm purposcs but may also have applications in cnntcxhial document processing. div.head: Document Image Decoding
div.p: A radical paradigm shift that unifies some aspects of preprocessing (e.g., line finding), layolit analysis, and character rucognition, was Kupcc and Chuu's 1451 Douunzuirf Irriagc Ducoding. DID draws, on m e hand, on communica tioiis theory and oil successful applications of HMM tn speech recognition and, on thc d w r , on thc side-bearing murlel of charactcr placcmciit and on simple mtidels of iioisc for printed p a p . Thcy mndd cadi column uf k x t as R Markov source (Fig. 7 ) whose transitions pciwratc character placements, white spaces, line feeds, carriage returns, a n d character bitmaps that are degraded by printing and scanning ("charmel noise"). The decoding proccss, basccl on dynaniic programming, attcmpts to idcntify the most likely sequence nf transitions froin thc obscrvcd pixcls. The rcquircd input consists uf character tcmplatecs that prodiice nonovcrlnpping character bi tniaps, transition probabilities of character classes, and thc frcqucncics of transitions that gcmurii tho layout.

A inodel with 1,700 nodes and over 6,000 b r a n c h was run on 48 cdumns from tcn pngcs from the Yellow Pages in about 36 hours (on a SPARCstatioiilO). The error rate on thc listings was lcss thnn 2 percent for names, and less than 0.5 pcrccnt for telephonc numbers. For this task, the font mctrics and samplc characters were extractcd froin training p p c s with a bitmap cditor (which was n noteworthy contribution in its own right). The character templatcs were obtninod by manual labcling of bitmap clustccrs. Tlie asymmetric bik-flip channel pacamctcr was estimated frriin thc variation among tlw glyphs in a cluster.

Within a year or so, Kilm and Kopcc I391 speeded up their rcador by up to 25 times, depending on the regularity of the layout. Tlic key was factoring the model into separate Markov processes for horizontal and vortical traversals. Huuristiically bounding thc contribution of unlikely paths in the Wcrbi trellis allows ctmccntrating the proccssiiig for each linc! of tcxt along its basclinc and, therefore, on a single chain of characl-L.r-to-cl~aracter transitions. Tlie heuristics that allow kruncating unpromising paths exploit thc consistency of black pixel distributions at different heights abovc h e baseline, the strong vertical stroke structurc, and the corrclnlion between neighboring pixels at 300 dpi.

The next contribution was ail improved method of template generation froin labeled samplcs of text 1461. It is an iterative waltz: 1) estimate glyph alignmeilt with the currcnk pnramcters; 2) refine thc template estimates by aligning aud thrcsholding the glyphs of cach class; 3 ) refine the channel parameter estimates. Thc initial template estimates awe composite bitmaps generated from four PostScript fonts. The results comparcd favorably with thosc of 'Yextl3rid.ge in a test of over a milliw characters of bodytext, especially when a fcw of the templates were rnanually edited. Kopcc and Loinelin 1461 found that using incorrect TextBridge labels, instead of the ground truth, for supervised template cstimation required ~ldditional template editing. This is the only comparison that we found in PAM1 between a research classifier and B commercial (albeit i ti-liousc) classifier.

div.head: PAGE DECOMPOSITION
div.p: As mentioned in Section 3, page decomposition can bc divided according to the naturc of the extracted struclurc.

To facilitate OCR, it is necessary only to separate text from nontext. Further proccssing is facilitated by partitioning text into columns and paragraphs, iiontcxt into line a r t and halftones, and demarcating tabular i40gioi1s. Beyond this point, thcrc is a choice betwcen dotailcd modeling Cor identifying logical and functional components through typographic attributcs, and delaying such analysis until the OCR results are available.

All of the work on physical decomposition that we found, and report in Scction 4.1, was published sincc 1993 and addresses technical journals. Two papers in Section 4.2 are about logical decomposition, i.e., identifying document coinponents for contcnt-based processing. They analyze technical articles and mail sorting. Section 4.3 covers tables and forms (and so docs the first paragraph of Section 4.1). We consider tubles as a mcnns of presenting information, andforms as a means of collecting information r211. They can be distinguished according to whether thc cells are printed at the same timc as, or before, the cell contents. We group them together because forms often have a tabular layout; therefore, many proccssing steps are similar.

div.head: Physical or Geometric Layout
div.p: The tabic of conteiits of technical jouriinls cxhibit a pleasing variety of layouts and ctiallcnging configurations of titlcauthor-page associatinns. A converted machi ne-vision buff dcvuloped a robust, rotation-invariant, data-driven mcth-hod for extracting complex pagc layouts including tables of cor~tcnt (TOCs) [a]. Document spectrum (rlocstrum) analysis clustcrs the connected componcnts by a nearestneighbors algorithm with a n nrientatinn-scnsitive metric (Fig. 8). Most of the required paramcters are estimated adaptively fi.oin size histograms on the page. Docstrurn was s~iccessfully applied to thousands of TOCs at the Bell Laboratories Libraries' IZightPnp information diffusinii system. Subsequently, O'Gorman and Knsturi co-authored the influential and rcfcrcnce-studded Pocummt Image A nnl ys is.

Multiscale segmentation methods that are popular in machine-vision can alsu be uscd to partition a gray-scanned page into f u f , imnge, and graphics regions [19]. Rotationinvariant features at diffcrcnt scales are derived from wavclet packets. Neural nctworks are used to differentiate the textures. Neighboring blocks arc firzzily combined by weightcd voting within and across scales. Because texture or Eroqucncy based layout analysis often results in nested labels, mr,dclbased postprocessing was rcquired to rccovcr the rectilinear layout of the page.

An intuitive and quite general model of the rectiliricar physical layout of technical journals Icd to efficient bottom-up cxtraction of the text structure [74]. The reading order is found by traversing a minimum spanning tree where the edge lengths are the largor of the horizontal and vertical distances between the bounding boxes uf connected components. The subtrees of the tree correspond to physical layout units. Although the model assumes horizontal text lines, it tolcrates up to 5 degrees of skew. With the addition of a few hcuristics, a test on 98 pages from three journals of chcmistry required manual correction of only seven pages.

After extensive expcrimeiitation with Gabor texture filters implemented as convolution masks on gray-scale document images, fain and Yu [34] developed a much faster bottom-up method to partition a page into columns of I d , driiwings, imiTp, fable rcgiutis, and riders. Following the application of a hierarchical Hough transform to connected components, the estimated skew is accommodated by introducing gcneralized text lines. Foreground pixels are grouped into rcctangular blocks with adjacent samu-lcngth horizrintal runs preserved as nodes in a Block Adjacency Graph (BAG); see [38] for a similar idea. Thc BAG nodes are successively grouped into connectud components, text lines, and region blocks, and simultaneously inserted into a novel page tnodei. The segmcntcd regions are classified using empirical rules and thrcshdds. The model is a tree where the branches of the root correspond to the five types of entities, and the leaves are the BAG iiodes. Selected results from performance tests on 150 varied page images are illustrated in color. The paper contains an informed analysis and a thorough literature review of geometric and logical page decomposition.

All commercial OCR systems provide the option of manual or automatic zoning (the dccumposition of the page into text and nontext regions). The worst error made by autiiiuatic ztmirig is d~columnizatiorr, which fuscs adjacent columns and requires very unpleasant puatediting. In the context of the OCR evaluation conducted at the Information Science Research Institute, Kanai et al. [40] proposed a method for evaluating zoning accuracy according to a string-edit metric between the OCR outputs on automatically arid manually zoncd pages. Other methods for zoning evaluation are based 011 geometric comparison of the zone coordinates or of the assignment of individual pixels to the two classcs. Krishnamoorthy et al. [47] combincd the nested X-Y tree decomposition of rectangles into rectangles with recursive horizontal and vertical application o f a publication-specific "block grammar" to determine the major logical components of technical articlcs. This model-driven approach isolates spccilic document components for selective OCR. Tlic cffort rcquircd to construct the grammars in Icx/yncc notation is a drawback, as is skew sensitivity.

div.head: Logical or Functlonal Layout
div.p: Although Cohen et al. [14I dcvcloped the followjng process for handwritten addresses, it appears equally applicable to print. Bach part of the process is splendidly illustrated in the paper. Tlie aystoin (euphoniously called HWAIS) segments the address into lincs and words (a nontrivial task) and parses the gray-scale, 300 dpi address, according to the perrnissiblc sequences of P.O. Box, street nurr.bur, street, cify, s M c , and 5 or 9 digit zip-code. Abbrevia-tions are expandcd. 'I'hc crmfiidciitly rccagiiizcd ficlds are used to assist the recognition of the remaining fields through prwtai zip-code, street, and strcct number directories. The final nbjcctivc is to assign the clcvcn-digit delivery point code (UPC). Postal recognition systems ai'c set to run at a low error rate, and route rejects to a data entry terminal.

In some applications, document classification is a necessary precursor of intcrprckation. A distance measure bawd on a machine-learning approach was thoroughly analyzed in 1lSl. It measures the difference between two structural dcscriptions (expressed as well-formed formulas jn Michalski's cxtcnsion of the predicate calcuius for inductive infcrcncc) in tcrins uf substitutions leading to the most general unifier. Esposito ck al.

[18] mention, and describe in detail elsewhere, the application of this recondite formulation to the classification of 35 document images into seven classes using primitives like width, height, and relative position.

div.head: Tables and Forms
div.p: Ruled forins and tables lie in some sense between our categories of text and graphic documents. They arc a latecomer to IJAMI (in fact, none of the papers below address tnbles), but over one hundred papers on the subject have been published.

Starting out before 1990, Watanabe atid his colleagues [92] developed powerful methods for analyzing and classifying many different ruled layouts (primarily Japonese business forms). Their representation i s a classification tree, each leaf of which points to table-specific global and local structure trees. The classification tree is used to determine whether an incoming form is one of the current set; if not, a new leaf is sprouted. Thc nodm of the sbncture trees are singlc and rcpmting blocks. There are very few restrictions on accepted layouts. The most exciting aspect of this formulation is dynamic table-knowledge acquisition.

YII and Jain [97] applied BAGS (see above) tn the cxtraction of form frames and preprinted data. Templates were constructed from empty fmms and correlated with filled-in forms. Once the form was registered, they first extracted thhc prt.valent horizontal rulings, then traced thcm to the vertical rulings. 711c strokes of characters that overlap the framc arc reconstructed after removal of the line.

A data rather than model driven method to removo rulings was prcscntcd in 1821. Thc novelty of the paper was not so much thc rpmoval of long horizontal and vertical lincs, which is done routinely by a variety of methods in commcrcial forms processing, but that it was done with twc)-dimcnsional m~ultiresolution wavelet analysis (MRA).
Experimental results were demonstrated on f h ~c c financial forms. According to the authors, "'['hey indicate superb performance of the proposcd ncw approach for document processing."

Informys (Invoice-like formreader s!ystenr) is a high-levcl. approach to form data extraction [12]. The system processes rulings, logns, instruction fields, and information fields. These are reyrcscnted by nodes of attributed graphs whose arcs correspond to the relative positions of linkcd items. Thcrcforc an information field can be identified not only if it is in il fixed location, but also by its position rclative to a 1.0 fixed reference object, cx by its relative position with respect to twu urilixcd rcfcrence objects. The refcrcncc objects, like logos and instruction fields, are recugnizcd with neural netwnrks. Thc tcxt is recognized by wholc-word recognition and by string-matching against thc model text (after chaiactcr recognition). 'The mudcl for each form is constructed with an interactivc system. The system was tested 011 almost three hundred invoices (Fig. 9) with few errors.
The article contains a short analysis o f alternative approaches to forms prnccssing.

div.head: GRAPHICS RECOGNITION
div.p: 'lhc papers in the first subsection address operations on pixcls, runs, and line segments. TIic second subsection patis a wider range of abstraction from graphic symbols to nctlists and three-dimensional interprctation.

div.head: Primitives Extraction
div.p: Ui Zc~izu et ill. [I51 presented thcir formal analysis of the GR lGmlilr Keprusertlotiun) of a bilevel image long a f k r applying it to the large-scale convcrsioil of land register maps. The GK is a general-purpose structure of adjaccnt foreground runs similar to thc LAG and the BAG. It can be used for extracting conncctcd components, Euler numbcrs, diameters, convcx hulls, concavities, and convexities. It is also an efficient data structure for vectorjxatiun.

13ccausc of the large size of maps, thcre is a premium on spccd. Yaiiiada et al. [95] developed R set of mdtiailgled parallcl (MAP) anisotropic neighborhood operations, that they called dircctional morphology, for cartographic fcaturci;. Tlicy extracted linear features and hatchcd areas using a VITcc image processor attached to a SUN. The main contribution of this paper was the extension of the multiplane computational framework to symbol inatclung.

The fundamental priiblcm in line art analysis is accurate, fast vectorization. Since most drawings consist of an overwhelming majority of background pixels and long chains of connected foreground pixels, the trick is to avoid processing all the backgruund pixels while recovering the continuity d the foreground pixels, Most vectorization algorithms approximate curved lines by sequences o f short straight-line scgments, but that only postpones intcrpretation. Uori [MI applied to arc segmentation the orthogonal zig-zag vectorizatioi~ (OZZ) algorithm that he had developed a few years earlier, The basic zig-zag algorithm finds a chain of "bars." Arc centers are hypothesizcd at the intersections of the perpendicular bisccturs of straight-line segments with monotonically changing slopes. More complex pixel-level processing is required to detect circles, locate accurately thc ccnter and end points of circular arcs, maintain continuity with tangent lincs, and alleviate the cffccts of small holes and islands.

Furthci* cxperimentation evidently convinccd Dori's group to base arc segmcntatioil on fully vectorized images. The resulting incremental method [93], that progressively chcckv tlie cocircdarity of clustered arc fragments, is faster than thc above hybrid method. X t is also very accurate, as deinoi~strated both on a multitudc of synthetically generated bitmaps and on a "host" of real-life drawings including dashed arcs. The algorithm was rcportcd to work well on arc segments greater than 10 pixels in radius, 7r/4 in angle, and one pixel in width.

Dnri also revisited O Z Z and turncd it into the Sparse Pixel Vectorization (SPV) algorithm [ 171. SPV approximates arc fragments more accurately and visits only a subset of points on the medial axis of a segment. The tracing bounces from the edge of a strip to its center and, hence, to an edge fiuther along the curve. Points between the detected ccntcr points are interpolated. Line width is preserved. Special provisions are, of course, necessary for line endings, junctinns, and intersections. Several quality measures were dcvolopcd and applied to vectorization of complex drawings from different source's. As expected, the algorithms performed well. It takes 3 to 5 seconds for a 1,000 x 1, Olio pixel drawing with mderate line densities. The code for Sun Solaris is available by ftp. This article contains an informative discussion of vectorization and of the pros and cons of alternative appruachcs.

The separation of tuxt from graphics has been challcnging researchers for many years. A recent communicaticiii in PAMI [54] proposed extracting thc text by erasing all the pixels that are part of long lincar components, are in regions of low stroke density, belong to largc dense configurations, or art? not adjacent to a siring of similar components. This is accomplished in a series of steps that draw on the recognition of already idmtificd components and gradually isolate the text. Thc method was demonstrntcd on many examples, some with inixcd Chinese/l.atin/Greek/Arabic lettering or digits. Although most of the text was extracted successfully, it is marred by graphics residuals that would impede recognition.

div.head: Drawing Interpretation
div.p: In 1983, Hunke [8] extcndcd the notion of attributed programmed string grammars to graph grammars. Prugrammed grammars control the order in which productions are applied. An attribute can be the location of a vertex or the l w g f h of a line segment. The graph grainmar acts as a generator to transform thc graph representation of an input drawing to the graph represontation of its description. The method was applied tci schematic diagrams. Extensions were presented, without any direct application tn graphic documents, in [55]. In addition to his influential work in DIA, Burtke hosted and cditcd the 1992 SSPIZ, and was coeditor of the Hn?adbook uf Uitaritctur Recognition and Uocunretzt hinge Annlysis. Sometime bcforc 1983, researchers at the Toshiba Rcsuarch and Development Center reached the remarkable conclusion that drawing logic circuit schematics carefully on paper, scanning them on a drum scanner, recognizing them using a special-purpose computer, and correcting thc residual errors with an intmactive computer-aided drafting/design systcin, would be about twice as fast as cntcriiig and correcting them with CAD tools alone. Ozaki and his colleagues [6G] developcd tlw required automatic drawing interpretation system. Their article, which is one of the few detailed descriptions of an operational graphics-recognition system, has been widely citcd. Evcn now, it represents an endeavor far beyond thc scope of most academic rcscarcliers.

Ozaki ct al. [66] focused 011 the recognition of loop symbols that occur by tlic hundreds in logic diagrams. Their decision-tree-cont roll ed approach combined connected component analysis, thinning, filtering, lino tracing, multiple clipping-windows, 2 x 2 masks, geometric and topolo-gical features, and digital tcmylaks dcrivcd from drafting templates. They distinguishcd 93 clnssos of ~ymlmls divided into 14 subcategories. The image processor was implemented with special-purposc, pipelined, multiprocessor tiard- ware (this wzs probably initiated about 1980; the saiiie issw nf PAMI contains two articles about parailel imagc processing computers of the same vintage). A n interaclive decision-tree editor: provided the required support for adding new symbols and characters to the recognition logic. Character rccognition was accomplished with nttributed string matching developed earlier.

The system was tested in the development nf 79 gatearray circuits on over 8511 drawings of up to JIS A1 size (594 mm x 811 mm), gray-scanned at 250 dpi. The 'IO participating draftsmen wc'rc hold to strict drawing standards. Thc symbols wow rccogiikcd with less than 1 percent crror and lcss than 3 percent reject. Processing A1 drawings took 30 minutes, of which half was taken for symbol and character recognition. One catinol help wondering how much the trade-off between interactive graphics entry and automated drawing recognition has been affectcd by their relative progress in the intervening years.

At about the same time, Kasturi, nt Pcnnsylvania State University, began to systematically tackle tlw various subtasks of graphics conversion. With Flctchcr, he extracted strings of text from lint! drawings [20]. Their method is based on connected component analysis followed by thc application of the Hough transform to find isolated collinear blubs of the size predicted by area-histcigram analysis of all the components. The paper contains a listing of the requirements on the size and spacing of the characters for robust text extraction. (This papor really belongs in Seclioii 5.1, but is inclitded here for crmtiiuiity.)

In 1390, with a largc group of MS students, Kastiiri [42] developed the tuols ncccssary to identify outline and solid polygonal objects and their spatial containment hierarchy, circular arc segments, hatched areas, dashed lines, connectors between objects, and text strings (including phrases and words touching or overlapping tlic linc art). '['hey exploited many of thc same graphics techniques as Ozaki c t al., including coniwcted components, collinear compoiwnt grouping, thinning, boundary tracking, loop analysis. The image-specific parameters and thresholds that would have to bc modified for different applications are tabulated. A test imagc dcvdopcd fur tuning some of the algorithms (Pig. 10) found application as a bench rnark.

The next correspondence, with h i , nddrussed a n important component of mechanical drawings, thc dimension sets. ' h i s was also the targct of Dori's early research, published elsewhere. ANSI dimeiisions have a complex syntax for arrowhuads and tails, leaders, datum markcrs and fcature control frames. They are normally either horizontal or vertical, and although thc lcadcr pairs may cross other graphic components, the lettering is isolated. To avoid confusion with dashed lines and to take advantage cif the isothetic orientation, Eai mid Kasturi [49] abandoncd the Hough transform and resorted to tmciiig the text strings from small cnnnoctL*d compoiients suspected of characterhood. A large (20,000 lines of C cridu) and principled experimental systcm model.ed on the human perception cycle is prcscntcd in [35]. The incremental analysis strategy is imbcddcd in 191 yacc rules that gencratc a 313-state parser thal c o n t r d s R sct of low-level image prrlccssing routines. A set of schema classes describes solid, dashed, and chained lincs, solid aiid dashed curves, cross hatching, physical outlines, text, witncss and leader lines, and certain forms uf dimensioning. Each schcma inaintains geometric and structural clcscriptitriis of the entity it represents. Tracing the drawing can bc initiated autoinatically and refined with interactively specified start p i n t s and radii. The article is concerned more with methodology than performance. Like Icasturi's, the system had nrr provision for text recognition, but it could Teconstrwt (render) the recognized data structure for coniparison with tlihc original. Joseph and Pridmore [35] pointcd out that evaluating the system by comparing its output with tlic "correct" CAI, file would bc difficult becausc of tlihc many equivalent CAD mrrdcls of a drawing.

Thc fr~ccus of MARC0 is may retrieval by content using database techniques [MI. MAGELLAN (Map Acquisition of Ccographic L.abels by Legend Analysis) is the front-end imagc processing system for MARCO. Samct and Soffer used Ktinros (an image-processing software devclnpmcnt system) to extract symbols from 280 256 )r 2515 pixel bilevcl tiles of the red symbol layer of a large-scale map of parl: of Finland, scanned at 240 bpi. They also scanned, at lower rcsdution, the corresponding colored composite map. 'f'wtlnly-two classes of symbols were identified by a modified nearest-neighbors comparison uf h t w vt'c tocs (inomcnts, circularity, eccentricity, intersections, ctc.) with prr)tr,typcs cxtmctccd from the I.egend. The classificatirm was conducted in a user-verified modc on the first 50 tiles only. Misrecognized symbols were added to the prototype library. Thc remainiiig tiles were processed autcm"ical1y. The label, certainty (confidcncc valuc), location and scmantic category of the 1,W3 extrackd symbols were stored in a relational database. In addition to thc usual SQL interface, on easy-to-use GUI was developed. Most of the extensive testing addressed the image indexing and spatial infurmation retrieval aspects of the system, using queries likedisplay diI Inyer tiles fhnf cod& n becrch and display all composite and layer tiles thaf ctwlain nn fli$idd north ujii benull.

Interpretation of complete schcmatic diagrams that consist of symbols linked by comcction lincs is the topic of 1981. The test set of over 1.00 drawings includcd clccti.ica1 circuit diagrams, logic circuits, chemical plant schematics, and flowcharts. The oulput was a graph or a textual netlist indicating the location and type of symbols and their comicctivity. After out-sourced thinuing and vcctc)rizatioiI, and in-house manual text rctnoval (rcquircd, unlike in [35], whcrc the text is boxed without recognition), tlw graphic symbols are extracted using generic segmentation rules and matched to a domain-spccific library that contains hierarchical symbol descriptors. l'hc drawing is then traversed to identify the coiincctors and any missed symbols. 'lhc system contains an inksactive error-correction phase that automatically logs every user intcrvcnhi, h i t inany of the drawings were proccsscd pcrfcctly in a few seconds. Contributions were ctiupling domain-indcpendent algorithms with domain-specific knowlcdgc bnscs, and evaluation by interactive correction. The article ends with a cogent literature review.
The remaining articles assuinc that the necessary lowlevel processing has already bucn accomplished. They s i p i d that graphics isterprtaiion is waiting in thc wings.

An influential paper that traces the evolution r)f constraint satisfaction algorithms over mow than a decade is Mulder et al. Bergwhi and Levine [7] also analyze idealizcd sketch imps using constraints, but their goal is the characterization (using gems) and identification of a three-dimensional object (pot, flashlight, ironing board, stool, wineglass) from a single two-dimensional vicw. Because the emphasis is on high-level integra tion, some of the lowlevel operations arc carried out by hand. Thc main themes are part segmentation, part labeling and nbjcct modcl matching using Biederman's recognition-by-componcnts (RBC) notions. The conclusion of the article addrcsscs weak points of the approach that require furthcr rcscarch.

Finally, two articles by Nalwa [GO], [6'1] cxainiiic the constraints rm orthogonal projections of straight lines and conic curves, and those indiiccd by bilateral (reflective) symmctry as seen in two-dimensional sketches of threedimcnsioiial objects.

div.head: OUTLIERS
div.p: Any clustering algorithm must deal with outliers, aiid ours is no exception. We suiniiiarize here, some contribulions that are not near neighbors of any of the ones above.
An expanded index generated by garbling the stored indcx terms according to the confusion matrix of an QCR dcvice can improve precision and recall [57].

You can tell a book by its c w w . That is what Gotoh et al. [22] set out to prove. They scanned three scts of 750 magazine covers in a wide range of orientations. One set was used for training and two for rccognition. Different issues of the same magazine were considered separate classes. With some tuning, they reached a recognition rate of 94 percent using decisiontree-bawd clustering.

Peak locations in the waveforms of transversal scans of alternating black and white bars are less sensitive to blur than edges. Joseph and Pavlidis [36] demonstrated that a decoder based on careful analysis of the peaks compared favorably with commercial bar-rude recognition rates of the order of one error per million. Bar codes arc often used in document indexing and some scanners have a bar-code printer.

Using thc word docirnre,it, in the sense of personal document, or photo identification card, the irrepressible OGorman proposed with Rabinovich, a method of secure document verification [64]. His objective was to determine whether a scanned photo is, or is not, the same as the originally scanned photo. Differences in the photo-signatrirc between tlw two digitized itnages may arise due to scanning and to physical dctcrioration of the printed photo betwccn the two scans. The method encodes several multiresolution versions of the photo (constructed from the highest resolution image) into a few dozen bytes according to the relative intensities of adjacent pixels. The photo-signature (a well-chosen term) yielded error rates of under '1 percent on a few hundred small mug shuts (from the NIST database) gray-scanned at 300 dpi. O'Gorman suggested that ihc signahires be stored in a central database, or combined with some textual information, encrypted with thc ANSI standard nigilal Signature Algorithm, and stored on thc identification card itself. Alternative identification methods bawd on signatures, fingcrprints, and face recognition are discussed elsewhere in this issue.

div.head: PROBLEMS SOLVED AND PROBLEMS REMAINING
div.p: We Preprocessing has come a long way. Adequate tcchniqws arc available for binarizing high-contrast documents.

On the other hand, it may be linic to cuncede that many document images cannot be binarhed without extensive gray-lcvcl analysis (that underminos the economies of binarization). Additive noise and isolated specks have been filterud and averaged out and are now on thc elidangered species list. Many good tccliniques have been developed for precise global skew estimation (but this is now less important than accurate word basclinc determination). Excellent methods are available for locating all the text on high-contrast printed pages down to the word level with an accuracy that exceeds that of subsequent steps.

Techniques for recognizing isolated document-objccts may already have reached a platcau. Tlic error rate on isolated characters, OCR fonts, clean print, and onedimensional bar codes is s ~) low that it is difficult to conduct significant experiments in a research setting. That is also the case for segmciitcd graphics primitives and for vectorization of high-quality line drawings and map separates. String matching turnad out to provide a sound foundation for accurate OCR evaluation and benchmarking, and informative error-reporting formats have emerged. Equally reliable comparison mctliods have been proposed so far only for computer-gcncrated graphics.

Current inodol-driven methods can home in on the framework of most forms and tables. Adequate interactive methods arc available for model specification starting with either blank or filled-in forms. It appears that robust validokion of cell content in known forms can be accomplished with cross-chccks and ad hoc methods that access databascs, directories, and dynamic work-flow systems, but no supporting theory has crncrgcd so far. It is time tn move beyond table geometry. Among minor achievements, DIA-oriented interpretations have been discovcred far almost all of the 2G3 TLAs (three-letter acronyms). Will FLAs be next?

div.head: Problems Remaining
div.p: There are still a few aspccts of preprocessing that might benefit from incrcascd attention. :Exploiting compressed formats for improving the spccd of subsequent processing remains appealing. We need to find better techniques for color separation o f few-color documents and halftone backgrounds or expioit color as we do gray scale. The reconstruction of overlapping rulings and text (often the result of printing from multiplc source layers) needs building on some good beginnings.

We arc far from being able to c{invcrt complex enginceriiig drawings and maps to any CAD format. lnstcad of attempting tu build graphics interpretation from the ground up, perhaps we should bcgin where the commercial systems leave off. To the extent that human intervention remains nccussary, we might givc more thought to whew it is best applied a i d how the automated parts of the system can profit from it.

OCR rcscarch must aim tn decrease ci'ror rates by more than an order uf majpitude on poor images from old fax machines, copiers, or high-speed printing on cheap paper. It is vexing that language context hclps least where acciiracy is most important, as on propcr nouns and numcric fields! Several directions c m be explorcd:

Feature-based multifont document image dccr>ding; Adaptation of more direct I-IMM methods to twodimensional document pixel maps (instead of considering text lines as a form of speech); Largc-vocabulary word or partial-word rccngnition combined with word-transition probabilities; Style-based recognition that exploits consistency of typeface, layout, and documcnl-quality; and Application-oriented benchmarking and classification of tccliniqucs. We can nwcr resist pi4osdytizing for Ieaming and adaptation. Pcrhaps static rccognition is now good enough to Lakc a frcsh look at dynamic systems. Confidently recognized pat terns can hclp identify their inore ambigiious brethren. (The speech community is certainly moving in that direction. Bootstrap training is widely used h r HMM). Exploiting feedback from human editing and downstream validation stiftwarc that rcflects the application-specific error pntkrns should lead to systems that improve with use. JZecent theoretical results that cxplorc the combination of supcrviscd aiid unsupervised learning might apply. Pcrlxips tlw SSS (syntactic, structural, and statistical) fedciation should seck a rapprochement with the machinc-learning community. Document content tagging is just around the corner. XML will play ail important role as a target representation in application-specific DIA. Extracthg XML tags will require a principled approach to the critical interface between DlA front-ends and back-ends that incorporate database managemcnt systems, wwk-flow, or formal table-models. Similar considerations apply to drawings and high-level CAD/ CAM data interchangc standards, and to maps and GIs. 13IA products cannot bo expected to function in isohtion.

Computer-generated documents in impoverished digital h m a t s that preclude full access to content are proliferating. Aspccts that differentiate such indigenous document images from scanned documents provide fresh opportunities for DIA, and help to legitimize claims to multimodn lity.

Better evaluation remains, as always, on the to-do list: metadata for mostly-text, live documents for mostlygraphics, and content-based evaluation for everything. What are repme,{tatzve documents? We still have no idea how to conduct a document census, cspeciaily on khc wcb. Nor do we know how to systematically select and combine teclnniques (i.e,, design systems) for specific document types m c l application requi remcnts.

We hope that we have inspired you to browse some of the back issues of PAMI (at least those that are already posted on thc web-at thc tiine of writing the rest are still waiting Cur iinprovcincnts in DIA). That is all, at lcast for now.

are now ready to look back at what we have wrought in the last 20 years. Mulling over what we have seen in PAMI and elsewhere, we shall try to assess how far we have come and where we are heading.

row.cell: Our work is getting easier! Thc major boon to U l h has been
the advent of CCD scanners that arc far superior to the CRT
and drtiin scanners of the pioneers. Consistent, high-
volume, high-rcsolution, gray-scale, and color digitization
is no longer a bottleneck in research. The capabilities o f
desktop workstations keep overtaking those of special-
page compression has become mainly an issue of standar-

note.p: dization. JMG provides cvcn higher comprmsiun than CCITT-G4 and JnIG-2 will offer the long-sought means of information extraction from compressed documents.
